Award.AwardTitle: Ionic competition in protein-nucleic acid interactions
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, Dr. Junji Iwahara from University of Texas Medical Branch (UTMB) at Galveston is supported to investigate ionic interactions of proteins and nucleic acids. These proteins and nucleic acids form ion pairs that involve strong electrostatic interactions between positively and negatively charged groups. Ion pairs are important for biological molecular functions; however, it is not well understood how the macromolecular ion pairs are influenced by free ions in solution. The project team is using light-based methods (nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy) to study the interplay between free ions and macromolecular ion pairs at protein-DNA interfaces. Because ion pairs are important for many specific molecular association processes, deeper knowledge of the ion pairs at molecular interfaces facilitate development of synthetic compounds in the agricultural, pharmaceutical, and biotechnological industries. This project enables high school students to participate in the interdisciplinary research in the investigator's laboratory. Tours of the NMR facilities are offered to all high school students in UTMB's summer research program.

The overall goal in this research project is to understand competition between free ions and macromolecular ion pairs at an atomic level in a biological system. In particular, the project aims at understanding the relationship of the ionic competition to the molecular properties of protein-nucleic acid complexes. In forming intermolecular ion pairs, the charged moieties of protein side-chains and DNA phosphate groups compete with free cations (e.g. potassium ions) and anions (e.g. chloride ions) in solution. The research team is studying the ionic competition at molecular interfaces in the DNA complexes of the homeodomain DNA binding protein HoxD9 and the methyl-CpG-binding domain of MeCP2. NMR spectroscopy is used to study the influence of ionic competition at an atomic level. Isothermal titration calorimetry and stopped-flow fluorescence spectroscopy are used to study the influence of ionic competition on the thermodynamic and kinetic properties of the complexes at a molecular level. This research project is integrating biophysical methods with mutagenesis, to delineate the ionic competition and its role in the protein-nucleic acid interactions.

This project is jointly funded by the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Division of Chemistry and the Molecular Biophysics Cluster in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Biological fluids involve various organic and inorganic ions. These ions are crucial for biological macromolecules to perform their function properly in living organisms. Through electrostatic interactions, ions influence the functions of proteins and nucleic acids. The ions dynamically change their locations with respect to the macromolecular surface. The high mobility makes it difficult to characterize the ions interacting with proteins or nucleic acids.  

 

The overall goal in this NSF-supported project was to understand competition between free ions and macromolecular ions at an atomic level and the relation of the ionic competition to the molecular properties of protein-DNA complexes. The research team, which involved 10 researchers (4 graduate students, a postdoctoral fellow, 2 technicians, 2 staff scientists, and a professor), investigated how ions behave and influence the molecular properties of proteins (in particular, those called transcription factors), DNA, and their complexes. The primary means for research in this project was nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy. In NMR spectroscopy, interactions between microwaves and atomic nuclei are observed at a high magnetic field, which is >100,000-fold stronger than the Earth’s magnetic field in the United States. NMR spectroscopy can provide atomic-level information about dynamic processes where molecules are freely moving and interacting each other in a solution.

 

In this project, the research team developed NMR methods for investigating ions, charged protein side chains, and movement of proteins on DNA. These methods allowed the research team to successfully detect and analyze ionic interactions of proteins and DNA. Positive charges of protein side chains compete with free cations for negative charges on DNA. Likewise, negative charges of DNA compete with free anions for positive charges of proteins. It had been speculated that cations are strongly condensed around DNA but are released upon protein-DNA association. The ion release is considered to play an important role in high-affinity association of proteins to DNA. However, the notion of the ion release had been merely speculative and supported by only indirect experimental data on salt concentration dependence of binding affinity. By NMR spectroscopy, the research team was able to directly observe the ion release from the DNA surface when proteins bind to DNA. It was the first direct observation of the ion release caused by protein-DNA interactions. The research team found that the ions condensed around DNA are highly mobile and rapidly diffuse while interacting with DNA, suggesting that the impact of each ion release could be smaller than previously believed. However, the number of the release ions were larger than previously estimated. This compensates for the small entropic effect for each ion released. Combining NMR and fluorescence methods, the research team investigated how ions influence the molecular properties of proteins and DNA. The research team also investigated water molecules intervening the ionic interactions. The results from this project were reported in 7 peer-reviewed articles.

 

For broader impacts, this project also provided opportunities for 3 high-school students to participate in research under primary supervision of the graduate students. In conjunction with Office of Educational Outreach, University of Texas Medical Branch (UTMB), the research team also gave a tour of the NMR facility to participants in UTMB’s summer research program for high school students and explained the NSF-supported research.
